definitions: make the loud shrill cry characteristic of a rooster especially at dawn
speak proudly about an achievement or success in a way that annoys others
examples: The rooster crows every morning at five o'clock sharp
Several roosters began to crow as the sun came up
She couldn't stop crowing about her promotion at work
The winning team crowed about their victory for weeks

definitions: cover food with small pieces of bread before cooking to create crispy coating
examples: She crumbed the chicken cutlets before frying them golden
The chef taught us how to properly crumb fish fillets

definitions: break or cause to break into small fragments or pieces
gradually disintegrate or fall apart over time due to age damage or weakness
examples: The dry cookie crumbled when I picked it up
She crumbled the cheese over the hot pasta dish
The old castle walls are crumbling from centuries of weather
Their business partnership began to crumble after the disagreement

definitions: crush hard food with teeth making a loud grinding sound
process large amounts of numbers or data quickly especially under time pressure
examples: The children love to crunch on fresh carrots and celery
He crunched the ice cubes loudly during the movie
Our team needs to crunch these sales figures before tomorrow
The computer crunched the data all night to find patterns

definitions: lead or take part in an energetic organized campaign for social political or religious change
examples: She crusaded for environmental protection throughout her entire career
The activists crusaded against unfair labor practices in factories

definitions: form or cause to form a hard outer layer or covering on something
examples: The mud crusted on his boots after the long hike
Snow crusted over the path making it slippery to walk

definitions: form or cause to form crystals through cooling or evaporation process
make ideas plans or thoughts become clear definite and fixed in final form
examples: The sugar solution will crystallize as the water evaporates slowly
Salt crystallizes when seawater is left to dry in pans
Her business plan finally crystallized after months of brainstorming sessions
The committee's goals crystallized during the three-day planning retreat

definitions: cut food or other material into small cube-shaped pieces of roughly equal size
examples: Please cube the potatoes for the soup recipe
The chef cubed the meat before adding it to the stew

definitions: hit someone lightly with the hand especially on the head or ear
examples: The mother gently cuffed her son for his rude comment
The bear cuffed its playful cub with a massive paw

definitions: select or gather the best or most useful items from a larger group
reduce the size of animal population by selective killing for management purposes
examples: She culled the best photos from thousands taken during the trip
The editor culled interesting quotes from the lengthy interview transcript
Rangers had to cull the deer population to prevent overgrazing
Farmers cull weak animals from their herds to maintain quality

definitions: reach the highest or most decisive point after a gradual buildup or progression
examples: Years of hard training culminated in winning the Olympic gold medal
The festival will culminate with a spectacular fireworks display tonight

definitions: prepare and use land for growing crops or garden plants
try to develop or improve a quality skill or relationship through deliberate effort
examples: Local farmers cultivate rice in the fertile valley fields
She cultivates organic vegetables in her backyard garden plot
He worked hard to cultivate friendships with his new colleagues
Parents should cultivate their children's natural curiosity about the world

definitions: restrain limit or keep something under control to prevent it from becoming excessive
examples: The government introduced new laws to curb pollution from factories
She needs to curb her spending habits before going into debt

definitions: form or cause to form a curved or spiral shape
play the sport of curling by sliding stones on ice toward a target
examples: Her hair naturally curls in humid weather conditions
The cat curled into a ball on the warm blanket
They curl every Tuesday evening at the local ice rink
She learned to curl during her vacation in Scotland

definitions: groom a horse with a special brush to clean its coat
try to win favor from someone through flattery or special attention
examples: The stable hand curries the horses every morning before riding
She carefully curried her show horse until its coat gleamed
He constantly curries favor with the boss by bringing coffee
Politicians curry favor with voters by making popular promises

definitions: use offensive or vulgar language especially to express anger or frustration
invoke supernatural power to inflict harm or punishment on someone or something
examples: He cursed loudly when he hit his thumb with the hammer
The angry driver cursed at the traffic jam ahead
The witch cursed the prince to sleep for a hundred years
Local legends say pirates cursed the island before they left

definitions: reduce the extent quantity or duration of something by imposing limits or restrictions
examples: The company had to curtail production due to supply chain issues
Bad weather curtailed our plans for the outdoor wedding ceremony

definitions: protect from the full force of an impact or reduce the effect of something harmful
examples: The airbag cushioned the driver during the sudden collision
Emergency savings can cushion the blow of unexpected job loss

definitions: modify or build something according to individual requirements preferences or specifications
examples: They customize each wedding cake according to the couple's wishes
You can customize your new laptop with additional memory and storage

definitions: convert a message into code or solve a coded message using specific methods
examples: Military personnel cypher sensitive messages before transmission to headquarters
She spent hours trying to cypher the ancient symbols

definitions: press lightly and repeatedly with something soft to clean or apply substance
examples: She dabbed the wound gently with a cotton ball
He dabbed cologne behind his ears before the date

definitions: waste time through aimless activity or unnecessary delay
have a casual romantic or sexual relationship without serious intentions
examples: Don't dally on your way home from school today
He dallied over breakfast while reading the morning newspaper
She dallied with several suitors but never committed to anyone
The prince dallied with the village girls during summer

definitions: build a barrier across a river or stream to hold back water
examples: Beavers dam the stream using branches and mud
Engineers will dam the river to create a new reservoir

definitions: make something slightly wet or moist without soaking it thoroughly
reduce the intensity strength or vigor of something to make it less extreme
examples: Damp the cloth before wiping the dusty furniture
Morning dew had damped the grass in the garden
The rain damped their enthusiasm for the outdoor picnic
Thick curtains help damp the noise from the street

definitions: make something slightly wet or humid by adding small amounts of moisture
make someone feel less enthusiastic excited or confident about something
examples: Dampen the sponge before cleaning the kitchen counter
She dampened her hair before styling it with gel
The bad reviews dampened our excitement about seeing the movie
High prices dampened consumer demand for luxury goods

definitions: make or become darker by reducing light or adding dark color
make or become gloomy threatening or depressed in mood or atmosphere
examples: Storm clouds darkened the afternoon sky within minutes
She darkened her hair from blonde to deep brown
His expression darkened when he heard the bad news
The political situation darkened as tensions increased between nations

definitions: repair a hole in fabric by weaving thread across it in a pattern
examples: My grandmother taught me how to darn socks properly
She darned the holes in his favorite sweater

definitions: move suddenly and rapidly in a particular direction like a small arrow
examples: The rabbit darted across the road into the bushes
Her eyes darted nervously between the door and window

definitions: run or move quickly for a short distance with sudden speed
destroy or ruin hopes plans or expectations completely and suddenly
examples: She dashed to the store before it closed
The children dashed across the playground to the swings
The injury dashed his hopes of competing in the Olympics
Bad weather dashed our plans for a beach vacation

definitions: spread a thick substance roughly or carelessly on a surface
examples: Children love to daub paint on paper with their fingers
He daubed plaster on the wall to fill the cracks

definitions: have pleasant thoughts and fantasies while awake instead of paying attention to surroundings
examples: She often daydreams about traveling to exotic tropical islands
Students sometimes daydream during long boring lectures at school

definitions: make someone unable to think or react properly through shock impact or bewilderment
examples: The bright explosion dazed everyone in the room momentarily
The complicated instructions dazed the new employees completely

definitions: blind temporarily with bright light or shiny reflections
greatly impress or overwhelm someone with skill beauty or brilliance
examples: The sun dazzled her eyes as she drove west
Spotlights dazzled the audience when the show began
The magician's tricks dazzled the children at the party
Her brilliant performance dazzled critics and audiences alike

definitions: make something stop being active or functional by turning off or disabling it
examples: Remember to deactivate the alarm before entering the building
The company will deactivate old user accounts after six months

definitions: officially prevent someone from doing something or entering somewhere as a punishment
examples: The athlete was debarred from competition for using banned substances
They debarred him from the club for breaking membership rules

definitions: remove money from a bank account or record an amount owed
examples: The bank will debit your account for the monthly service fee
Please debit my checking account for the purchase amount

definitions: find and remove errors from computer software or hardware to make it work correctly
examples: Programmers spent weeks debugging the new software before release
She had to debug her code to fix the crashing issue

definitions: expose the falseness of a belief claim or theory by presenting contradicting evidence
examples: Scientists debunked the myth that we only use ten percent of our brains
The investigation debunked claims of fraud in the election

definitions: rot or cause to rot through natural process of decomposition over time
examples: Dead leaves decay on the forest floor enriching the soil
Sugar in your mouth can cause teeth to decay

definitions: deliberately cause someone to believe something false through lies or trickery
examples: The con artist deceived elderly people out of their savings
Don't let his friendly manner deceive you about his intentions

definitions: convert coded or unclear message into understandable language through analysis and interpretation
examples: Archaeologists worked years to decipher the ancient stone inscriptions
I couldn't decipher his handwriting on the prescription

definitions: convert coded message or data back into understandable form using known methods
examples: The spy needed special equipment to decode the encrypted messages
Scientists decode DNA sequences to understand genetic information

definitions: officially remove equipment or facilities from active service often permanently
examples: The navy will decommission several old ships this year
They plan to decommission the nuclear plant after forty years

definitions: decay or rot through natural biological process breaking down into simpler substances
break something down into constituent elements or simpler components for analysis
examples: Fallen leaves decompose slowly creating rich soil for plants
The body had decomposed beyond recognition in the heat
Scientists decompose water into hydrogen and oxygen using electricity
We need to decompose this problem into smaller manageable tasks

definitions: analyze text or idea by breaking it down to expose assumptions and contradictions
take apart a structure or system methodically to understand how it works
examples: Literary critics deconstruct novels to reveal hidden meanings and biases
The professor deconstructed the argument to show its logical flaws
Engineers deconstruct old machines to learn their design principles
The chef deconstructed traditional recipes into modern presentations

definitions: add ornamental or festive features to something to make it more attractive
examples: They decorate their house with lights every December holiday season
The baker decorated the wedding cake with sugar flowers

definitions: lure person or animal into a trap or away from intended destination
examples: Hunters use wooden ducks to decoy real birds within shooting range
The thieves decoyed the guard away from his post

definitions: order something officially especially by legal authority or royal command
examples: The king decreed that all citizens must pay the new tax
The court decreed that custody be shared between both parents

definitions: change laws so that something is no longer treated as a criminal offense
examples: Several states voted to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana
The government plans to decriminalize certain minor traffic violations

definitions: convert encrypted data back into readable form using the appropriate key or password
examples: You need the password to decrypt these confidential files
The software can decrypt messages sent using this security protocol
